abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Social Sectors Development Project
            (SSDP) in Jamaica. This report provides an evaluation of the
            implementation of the SSDP with particular emphasis on
            lessons learnt from the experience. The main objective of
            SSDP was to improve the efficiency, delivery and management
            of social services in Jamaica, and in particular of health
            and education. The other objectives were as follows: (i)
            continued support for the ongoing program of economic
            adjustment; (ii) selected investments in key economic and
            social sectors, combined with policies to improve the
            efficiency of resource use and combat the worst effects of
            poverty; and (iii) assistance to the government in securing
            the external financing needed for its development program.
            Overall, Bank performance was marginally satisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned from the implementation experience of this
            project follows: (a) project design must reflect the
            institutional capacities of agencies to execute the
            activities and incorporate adequate strengthening measures
            beyond the hiring of additional staff; (b) the better
            integrated project implementation units and their activities
            are within the implementing agency the greater the
            probability is of objectives being achieved and sustained.;
            (c) new options for the management of civil works must be
            seriously considered and piloted; (d) introducing
            post-qualification to better evaluate the contractor's
            financial and technical resources at the time the works are
            to be undertaken; (e) specific project outcome and impact
            measures in addition to input and output indicators should
            be established during design, evaluated as part of the
            project and consistently monitored to determine project
            achievement and development impact; and (f) it is
            unreasonable to expect an investment project which disburses
            on the basis of narrowly-defined outputs and contributes a
            marginal amount to overall sector spending to effect
            wide-reaching policy reform.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Social Sectors
            Development Project are to improve the efficiency, delivery
            and management of social services in Jamaica, and in
            particular, of health and education. It will support the
            Government's Human Resources Development Program
            (HRDP). The project will finance: civil works, furniture,
            equipment (including vehicles)), pharmaceuticals, books,
            training, consultants' services, and incremental HDRP
            staff for: health sector development; education sector
            development; HDRP administration and monitoring.
